questions.text: MATCH THE FOLLOWING:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation

 

  • Statins inhibit HMG CoA Reductase (d), a key enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis.
  • Dicoumarol inhibits Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase (c), affecting the clotting cascade.
  • Methotrexate inhibits Dihydrofolate Reductase (b), used in cancer therapy and autoimmune diseases.
  • Succinyl Choline is not an enzyme inhibitor but a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor agonist used as a neuromuscular blocker; however, in the context of this question, it's matched with Acetylcholinesterase (a) by process of elimination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibitors of enzymes are mostly drugs

 

 

Some competitive inhibitors which are not drugs are

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 81-84.

questions.text: Match the clinically useful competitive inhibitors with the drug:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

Explanation:

A. Allopurinol is a competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, an enzyme involved in the pathway that leads to uric acid production. Therefore, it is used in the treatment of gout.

B. Sulfonamide is a competitive inhibitor of pteroid synthetase (also known as dihydropteroate synthase), an enzyme involved in folate synthesis in bacteria.

C. 5-fluorouracil is a competitive inhibitor of thymidylate synthase, an enzyme involved in the synthesis of the nucleotide thymidine, which is required for DNA replication.

D. Trimethoprim is a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme involved in the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, which is necessary for the production of purine and pyrimidine nucleotides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 61

questions.text: A 19-year-old African female presents with chronic, mild symptoms of sleeping sickness, persisting over two years. She is treated with difluoromethyl ornithine (DFMO), known for its efficacy against trypanosomiasis. DFMO inhibits the enzyme involved in polyamine synthesis, crucial for the parasite's proliferation. Based on DFMO's mechanism, what type of enzyme inhibition does it exemplify?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Suicidal Inhibition

 

Option A.

 

  • It is also known as mechanism-based inactivation. 
  • Here the inhibitor makes use of the enzyme’s own reaction mechanism to inactivate it.
  • In suicide inhibition, the structural analog is converted to a more effective inhibitor with the help of the enzyme to be inhibited.
  • For example, ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) catalyzes the conversion of ornithine to putrescine which is important for polyamine synthesis. Thus, when the ODC in trypanosoma is inhibited → multiplication of the parasite is arrested. Therefore, inhibitors of ODC enzyme such as difluoromethyl ornithine (DFMO) are found to be effective against trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness).
  • A similar mechanism is noted in the case of Allopurinol which is oxidized by xanthine oxidase to alloxanthine which is a strong inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.
  • The anti-inflammatory action of Aspirin is based on the suicide inhibition. Arachidonic acid is converted to prostaglandin by the enzyme Cyclo-oxygenase.  Aspirin acetylates a serine residue in the active centre of cyclo-oxygenase, thus prostaglandin synthesis is inhibited and so inflammation subsides.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase, Fluoride inhibit enolase thereby consequently the glycolysis, Iodoacetate inhibit enzymes having –SH group in their active centers, BAL (dimercaprol) as an antidote for heavy metal poisoning etc.

 

Option C. Uncompetitive: Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan iso-enzyme) by phenylalanine.

 

Option D. Allosteric: ALA Synthase catalyse the first step in heme biosynthesis and the end product, heme will allosterically inhibit the enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DFMO acts as a suicidal (or suicide) inhibitor by irreversibly binding to and inactivating ornithine decarboxylase, the enzyme responsible for polyamine synthesis essential for the growth and reproduction of Trypanosoma brucei, the parasite causing sleeping sickness. Suicidal inhibitors form a covalent bond with the enzyme, leading to its permanent inactivation.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p78.

questions.text: In a case study involving the analysis of a new drug's mechanism of action, it's observed that the drug inhibits an enzyme by resembling the enzyme's natural substrate and competing for the active site. Given this mode of inhibition, how would this type of enzyme inhibition be classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Competitive inhibition

 

  • Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme, because the inhibitor is a structural analogue of the substrate.

           E + S <-> E–S → E + P

           E + I  <-> E–I

  • Since E-I (enzyme–inhibitor complex) can react only to reform the enzyme and inhibitor, the number of enzyme molecules available for E-S formation is reduced.

 

 

  • Competitive inhibition is reversible or excess substrate abolishes the inhibition.
  • The Km is increased in presence of a competitive inhibitor, thus the affinity of the enzyme towards the substrate is apparently decreased and Vmax is not changed.     

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Non-competitive inhibition: Inhibitors have no structural resemblance to the substrate.

 

Option C. Feedback inhibition: The activity of the enzyme is inhibited by the product of the reaction.

 

Option D. Allosteric inhibition: The inhibitor is not a substrate analog.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor molecule resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the enzyme's active site. This type of inhibition can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate, as both the substrate and inhibitor compete for the same site on the enzyme.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 59.

questions.text: In the context of studying enzyme inhibition mechanisms, succinate dehydrogenase, an enzyme in the citric acid cycle, is noted to be inhibited by malonate. This inhibition occurs because malonate closely resembles the enzyme's natural substrate, succinate, but cannot undergo the same reaction. Based on this information, what type of enzyme inhibition does malonate exemplify when inhibiting succinate dehydrogenase?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Competitive.

 

Option C.

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor molecule resembles the substrate's structure and competes for binding to the enzyme's active site. Since malonate competes with succinate for the active site of succinate dehydrogenase but does not undergo the subsequent reaction, this is a classic example of competitive inhibition. Increasing the concentration of the substrate (succinate) can overcome this type of inhibition, as it can outcompete the inhibitor (malonate) for the active site.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Non-competitive: Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase, Fluoride inhibit enolase thereby consequently the glycolysis, Iodoacetate inhibit enzymes having –SH group in their active centers, BAL (dimercaprol) as an antidote for heavy metal poisoning etc.

 

Option B. Uncompetitive: Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan iso-enzyme) by phenylalanine.

 

Option D. Allosteric: ALA Synthase catalyse the first step in heme biosynthesis and the end product, heme will allosterically inhibit the enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examples of competitive inhibition

 

Competitive inhibitors of enzymes are mostly drugs

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p78.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with stage II breast cancer has undergone modified radical mastectomy (MRM) with axillary clearance. As part of her adjuvant therapy, she is prescribed an anticancer drug that acts as a competitive inhibitor of Thymidylate Synthase, an enzyme crucial for DNA synthesis. Which of the following drugs has been recommended to inhibit Thymidylate Synthase and potentially reduce cancer cell proliferation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 5-Fluorouracil

 

Option D.

 

It is an analog of uracil or thymine.

Fluorouracil will inhibit thymidylate synthase → reduces the conversion of dUMP to dTMP → reduces the thymine incorporation in the DNA → thus consequent DNA synthesis is prevented.

It is used in the treatment of adenocarcinoma of colon and breast.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Option A. Lovastatin – Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase, used for lowering cholesterol.
  • Option B. Neostigmine – Reversible cholinesterase inhibitor used in myasthenia gravis.
  • Option C. Allopurinol – Inhibits xanthine oxidase, used in gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is an antimetabolite chemotherapeutic agent that acts as a competitive inhibitor of Thymidylate Synthase. By inhibiting this enzyme, 5-FU prevents the synthesis of thymidine monophosphate, a nucleotide essential for DNA replication and cell division, thereby exerting its anticancer effects.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 61.

choices.text: Km remains same & Vmax increases
Km remains same & Vmax decreases

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with hypertension and type 2 diabetes is prescribed a new drug to lower her cardiovascular risk. This drug acts as a non-competitive inhibitor for an enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis. What effect does this inhibitor have on the enzyme's kinetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Km remains same & Vmax decreases

 

Option B.

 

Features of Non-competitive Inhibition

 

  • The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, other than the substrate binding site and the inhibitor has no structural resemblance to substrate and hence, excess substrate does not abolish the inhibition.

 

 

  • The inhibitor combines with the enzymes by a covalent bond, which makes the reaction irreversible.
  • The velocity (Vmax) is reduced, and the Km value is not changed, because the remaining enzyme molecules have the same affinity for the substrate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Km remains the same & Vmax increases: This is incorrect because non-competitive inhibition typically reduces the maximum reaction rate, not increases it.

 

Option C. Km decreases & Vmax increases: This option is incorrect as non-competitive inhibitors do not affect the enzyme's affinity for its substrate (Km would remain unchanged) and would not increase the maximum reaction rate (Vmax).

 

Option D. Km decreases & Vmax decreases: While non-competitive inhibitors decrease Vmax, they do not affect the enzyme's affinity for its substrate, so Km would not decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an enzyme at a site other than the active site. This binding doesn't affect the enzyme's affinity for its substrate, so the Michaelis constant (Km) remains unchanged. However, it reduces the enzyme's catalytic efficiency, leading to a decreased maximum velocity (Vmax) of the reaction.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 81.

choices.text: It is an uncompetitive inhibition
The inhibitor binds only to free enzyme
Heavy metal poisons are irreversible non-competitive inhibitors.

questions.text: Based on the depicted interactions, which statement is true about the mode of inhibition illustrated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Heavy metal poisons are irreversible non-competitive inhibitors.

 

Option D.

 

The diagram indicates that the inhibitor can bind to the enzyme whether or not the substrate is present, which typically characterizes non-competitive inhibition. However, option D is specifically true in the context of heavy metal poisons, which can act as irreversible non-competitive inhibitors by binding to the enzyme and altering its structure and function in such a way that it cannot be reversed.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is uncompetitive inhibition: This is incorrect because uncompetitive inhibitors only bind to the enzyme-substrate complex, and the inhibition is usually reversible.

 

Option B. The inhibitor binds only to free enzyme: This is incorrect, as the diagram shows the inhibitor binding to both the enzyme and the enzyme-substrate complex, not just the free enzyme.

 

Option C. No product is formed: This might be a result of the inhibition shown, but it doesn't describe the type of inhibition or the nature of the inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of Non-competitive Inhibition:

 

  • The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, other than the substrate binding site.
  • A non-competitive inhibitor binds to both free enzyme and enzyme substrate (ES) complex → [EI] or [ESI] complex is formed → product formation is slowed down and not halted.
  • The inhibitor has no structural resemblance to substrate.
  • Hence, excess substrate does not abolish the inhibition.
  • The inhibitor combines with the enzymes by a covalent bond, which makes the reaction irreversible.
  • The velocity (Vmax) is reduced and the Km value is not changed, because the remaining enzyme molecules have the same affinity for the substrate.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 60.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is right but R is a wrong statement
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion(A): Enzyme inhibitors act as metabolic poisons.

Reasoning(R): Enzyme poisons reversibly or irreversibly inhibits the action of enzymes involved in metabolic processes, thereby affecting the metabolic pathways.

Based on these statements, which of the following best describes their relationship?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

 

Explanation:

 

ENZYME POISONS:

 

  • Enzyme inhibitors act as metabolic poisons.
  • Many poisons work by inhibiting the action of enzymes involved in metabolic processes, which hampers the metabolic pathways.
  • Enzymes poisons are basically enzyme inhibitors and this inhibition can be reversible or irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 61.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is right but R is a wrong statement
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describes the action of Disulfiram, a drug used in the treatment of alcoholism? 

 

Assertion(A): Disulfiram is used for treating alcoholism 

 

Reasoning(R): It inhibits the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase helps in alcohol avoidance:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A is right but R is a wrong statement

 

Explanation:

  • Assertion (A):
    True.
    Disulfiram is indeed used in the treatment of alcoholism as an aversion therapy drug.
  • Reason (R):
    False.
    The mechanism of action of Disulfiram is NOT by inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase.
    Instead, it inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, the enzyme that converts acetaldehyde to acetate.
    As a result, after alcohol consumption, acetaldehyde accumulates in the body, leading to unpleasant symptoms (flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache), which discourages alcohol intake.

 

Thus:

  • A is correct (Disulfiram is used for alcoholism),
  • R is incorrect (wrong enzyme mentioned).

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A:
    Incorrect, because R is wrong.
  • Option C. A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A:
    Incorrect, because R is false.
  • Option D. A and R both are wrong:
    Incorrect, since A is true.

Educational Objectives:

  1. Understand the Pharmacology of Disulfiram:
    • Recognize that Disulfiram inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase (not alcohol dehydrogenase).
  2. Know the Rationale for Use:
    • Disulfiram causes acetaldehyde accumulation, leading to disulfiram-ethanol reaction—this forms the basis of its aversion therapy.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 140.

choices.text: A and R both are right, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is right but R is a wrong statement
A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion(A): Methotrexate competitively inhibits folate reductase due to its structural similarity to folic acid. Cancer cells develop resistance if the drug is taken for a long time.

 

Reasoning(R): Drug resistance is by gene switching.

 

Which of the following best assesses the relationship between the assertion and the reasoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A is right, but R is a wrong statement.

 

Option B:

 

  • Methotrexate is a widely used anticancer drug, which acts by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase.
  • It has structural similarity to folic acid and hence will competitively inhibit folate reductase → tetrahydrofolic acid is not produced, which is necessary for incorporation of C2 and C8 of purines and C5 methyl group in thymidine → inhibition of DNA synthesis and consequently cell division.
  • Methotrexate is employed in the treatment of choriocarcinoma and acute leukaemia.
  • In patients receiving methotrexate for a long time, the malignant cells starts developing drug resistance by increasing the number of genes for dihydrofolate reductase by gene amplification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, a key enzyme in the folate pathway, which is essential for DNA synthesis.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e, p 716,717.

questions.text: A 45-year-old firefighter collapses and becomes unconscious following intense exposure during a fire incident in a wool factory, a scenario suggestive of cyanide poisoning. Initial treatment included amyl nitrite and sodium thiosulfate, commonly used in such poisoning cases. The medical team considers additional antidote options to enhance the treatment regimen. Given the situation and the initial treatments administered, which of the following could also be used as an effective antidote for cyanide poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium nitrite

 

Option C:

 

Sodium nitrite is used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning as it helps by inducing methemoglobinemia. Methemoglobin has a higher affinity for cyanide ions than cytochrome oxidase enzymes, thus it can help sequester cyanide from the cytochrome oxidase enzyme system, allowing cellular respiration to continue. Sodium nitrite is often used in conjunction with sodium thiosulfate, which acts by converting cyanide to the less toxic thiocyanate.

 

SOURCES of Cyanide Poisoning:  Suicidal attempts, Industrial exposure to hydrocyanic (prussic) acid or potassium cyanide, Ingestion of amygdalin etc   tissue anoxia by chelating the ferric ions of intracellular respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Dicobalt edetate – antidote that chelates the cyanide.
  • I.V sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate (Nitrite converts Hb to MetHb → Ferric ion of MetHb takes up CN as cyanmethemoglobin → cytochrome oxidase becomes free of CN → also thiosulfate detoxifies CN by forming thiocyanate, which gets excreted).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dimercaprol (BAL): Dimercaprol is an antidote for heavy metal poisoning (such as arsenic, lead, and mercury) but not for cyanide poisoning.

 

Option B. N-acetylcysteine: N-acetylcysteine is an antidote for acetaminophen poisoning and works by replenishing glutathione, but it's not used for cyanide poisoning.

 

Option D. large doses of ethanol: Ethanol is used as an antidote for methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning due to competitive inhibition at the alcohol dehydrogenase enzyme but is not an antidote for cyanide poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment options for cyanide poisoning, includes the use of sodium nitrite as part of a combination therapy to induce methemoglobinemia and bind cyanide ions, thereby allowing cellular respiration to resume.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 767, 768.
